Question 9: How do gravity and pressure interact within stars, and what is the result of this interaction? Options: A. Gravity pulls matter inward, while pressure pushes it outward, resulting in a stable star., B. Gravity and pressure work together to create a massive explosion, destroying the star., C. Gravity pulls matter inward, but pressure has no effect, resulting in a collapsing star., D. Pressure pushes matter outward, but gravity has no effect, resulting in an expanding star. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the ongoing battle between gravity and pressure that continues to this day, and what is its significance? Options: A. The battle between gravity and pressure continues within every star, maintaining their stability., B. The battle between gravity and pressure continues on Earth, preventing the atmosphere from collapsing., C. The battle between gravity and pressure continues throughout the universe, shaping its structure., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6. 

This question addresses the concept of Baryonic Acoustic Oscillations (BAOs) and their role in shaping the universe's structure, which is the main focus of the ground truth MCQ. Although the generated MCQ does not directly ask about the definition of BAOs, it explores the interplay between gravity, pressure, and BAOs, which is closely related to the intent of the ground truth MCQ.

The correct option in Question 6 (Option C) mentions that BAOs were the result of gravity and pressure fighting, leading to the formation of galaxies and galaxy clusters. This is consistent with the information provided in the transcript and the ground truth MCQ, which describes BAOs as massive waves that determine the distribution of matter throughout space.

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 6.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Welcome one and all! It’s time to grab your seat
for the biggest battle in the soon-to-be-formed universe. That’s right— 
the Big Bang is about to go down! In one corner is the force that brings
all matter together. It acts on any particle with mass,
and its range is infinite— give it up for gravity! In the other corner, our contender can
push matter away with spectacular strength. When the going gets tough,
this fighter just gets tougher. That’s right, it’s pressure! Over the next several
hundred thousand years, these two contenders will be wrestling
for the fate of the universe. That’s right folks, the ripple effects
of this historic match will shape the structure of the universe
as we know it today. But what are these powers fighting over? We’ll find out when the Big Bang
hits right... now! Let’s zoom in for the play-by-play. This epic event has brought three
components into our infant universe. Dark matter, which only interacts
with gravity. Baryonic matter, which makes
up all matter you’ve ever seen, is affected by both gravity and pressure. And radiation composed 
of innumerable particles of light, also known as photons. In the moments just after the Big Bang, all three components are in equilibrium, meaning no one location
is denser than another. But as the universe starts expanding,
differences in density start to emerge. Gravity immediately gets to work
pulling matter together. Dark matter begins to collect
at the center of these increasingly
dense regions, forming the foundations
of future galaxies. Meanwhile, pressure begins gathering
its strength. In this hot, high-energy environment, protons and electrons can’t come
together to form atoms, so these loose particles zip around,
freely interacting with ambient photons. The result is almost a fluid
of baryonic matter and radiation. But the closer these baryonic particles
get, the hotter the fluid becomes, pushing photons to ping
around with incredible force. This is the power of pressure,
specifically radiation pressure, battling to push things apart. With each of gravity’s vicious tugs
squeezing photons and matter together, pressure exerts a forceful shove back. And as the two giants struggle,
they heave this fluid back and forth— creating massive waves called
baryonic acoustic oscillations. Moving at almost two thirds
the speed of light these BAOs ripple across space, impacting the universe
on the biggest scale imaginable. These rolling waves determine the
distribution of matter throughout space, meaning that today— almost 14 billion
years after this fight began— we're more likely to find
galaxies at their peaks and empty space in their troughs. And that’s not all. We can still see these ripples in the
background radiation of the universe, a permanent reminder of this epic brawl. But after being locked in a stalemate
for roughly 370,000 years, the tide of our battle finally
begins to turn. After all this time, the heat from the
Big Bang has dissipated significantly, cooling the universe down to a temperature at which loose electrons
start to pair up with protons. Known as the “era of recombination,” this stops electrons
from recklessly pinging around. This allows light to stream freely
for the first time, illuminating the universe. These photons now only exert a tiny force
on the neutral atoms they interact with, gradually reducing the power of pressure. And with that, it’s time to crown
our champion! The undefeated force,
the most pervasive power in the universe: it’s gravity! And yet, this rivalry isn’t over. A similar battle continues between these
two sworn enemies today, within every single star. As gravity pulls a star’s gas inward, pressure increases and pushes
the matter back outward. This push and pull keeps the Sun,
and all other stars, stable for billions of years. In fact, this clash of the titans
is the same reason Earth’s atmosphere doesn’t collapse
to the ground. So while their greatest fight
might have ended, these two warriors are still
to be locked in combat— even as a new challenger approaches.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What led to the end of this fight, about 370,000 years after the Big Bang?
Options: A. Electrons recombined with protons, decreasing the pressure of radiation on matter, B. The fight never ended: it is still occurring today, C. Radiation started to interact with dark matter as well, D. The Universe became too hot, and the fight could not be sustained any longer
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What two fundamental forces are described as fighting for the fate of the universe in the context of the Big Bang? Options: A. Gravity and electromagnetism, B. Gravity and pressure, C. Electromagnetism and the strong nuclear force, D. The weak nuclear force and dark energy Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the initial state of the universe after the Big Bang in terms of the distribution of matter? Options: A. Matter was evenly distributed throughout the universe., B. Matter was concentrated in certain regions, with large voids in between., C. Matter was in a state of constant motion, with no clear pattern., D. Matter was nonexistent in the early universe. Correct Option: A
Question 3: If the gravity of a star were to suddenly increase, what would be the expected outcome? Options: A. The star would expand and cool down., B. The star would contract and heat up., C. The star would remain unchanged., D. The star's pressure would increase to counteract the increased gravity. Correct Option: B
Question 4: How did dark matter, baryonic matter, and radiation interact in the early universe? Options: A. Dark matter interacted with both baryonic matter and radiation., B. Baryonic matter interacted with radiation, but not dark matter., C. Dark matter only interacted with gravity, while baryonic matter interacted with both gravity and pressure., D. Radiation interacted with neither dark matter nor baryonic matter. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the result of the battle between gravity and pressure in the universe, in terms of the distribution of matter? Options: A. Matter is evenly distributed throughout the universe., B. Matter is concentrated in certain regions, with large voids in between., C. Matter is in a state of constant motion, with no clear pattern., D. Matter is distributed in a web-like structure, with galaxy clusters and superclusters. Correct Option: B
Question 6: How did the interplay between gravity, pressure, and baryonic acoustic oscillations shape the universe's current structure? Options: A. Gravity pulled matter together, while pressure pushed it apart, resulting in a uniform distribution of matter., B. Gravity and pressure worked together to create massive waves that distributed matter throughout the universe., C. Baryonic acoustic oscillations were the result of gravity and pressure fighting, leading to the formation of galaxies and galaxy clusters., D. The universe's structure is the result of a combination of gravity, pressure, and electromagnetism. Correct Option: C
Question 7: What role did gravity play in shaping the universe as we know it today? Options: A. Gravity played a minor role in the universe's formation., B. Gravity was the dominant force in shaping the universe's structure., C. Gravity and pressure worked together to create the universe's current structure., D. Gravity had no impact on the universe's formation. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What is the era of recombination, and what was its significance in the battle between gravity and pressure? Options: A. The era of recombination was when electrons and protons first combined to form atoms, leading to an increase in pressure., B. The era of recombination was when gravity and pressure first began to interact, leading to the formation of galaxies., C. The era of recombination was when the universe's temperature cooled enough for electrons to pair up with protons, reducing the power of pressure., D. The era of recombination was when the universe's temperature increased, leading to an increase in pressure. Correct Option: C
Question 9: How do gravity and pressure interact within stars, and what is the result of this interaction? Options: A. Gravity pulls matter inward, while pressure pushes it outward, resulting in a stable star., B. Gravity and pressure work together to create a massive explosion, destroying the star., C. Gravity pulls matter inward, but pressure has no effect, resulting in a collapsing star., D. Pressure pushes matter outward, but gravity has no effect, resulting in an expanding star. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the ongoing battle between gravity and pressure that continues to this day, and what is its significance? Options: A. The battle between gravity and pressure continues within every star, maintaining their stability., B. The battle between gravity and pressure continues on Earth, preventing the atmosphere from collapsing., C. The battle between gravity and pressure continues throughout the universe, shaping its structure., D. All of the above. Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the event that led to the end of the fight between gravity and pressure, approximately 370,000 years after the Big Bang. The correct option in both questions refers to the era of recombination, when electrons paired up with protons, reducing the power of pressure.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
For 100 days in 1994,
the African country of Rwanda suffered a horrific campaign
of mass murder. Neighbor turned against neighbor
as violence engulfed the region, resulting in the deaths of over one-tenth
of the country’s population. The seeds of this conflict were
planted a century earlier, first when German, and later Belgian,
colonizers arrived in the country. At the time, Rwanda was ruled
by a monarchy of Tutsi, one of the three ethnic groups
comprising the population. Tutsi and the even smaller Twa communities
were minority groups, while Hutu composed the majority. Many Hutus and Tutsi civilians
were on good terms, but colonial powers encouraged
political division. Belgians enforced record keeping
around ethnic identity, and created a public narrative that cast
Tutsi as elite rulers and Hutu as ordinary farmers. Over time, this propaganda led 
to intense political hostility. And while colonial powers had
largely withdrawn by 1959, lingering anger motivated a Hutu revolt, forcing many Tutsi leaders
to flee the country. Over the following decade, Rwanda transitioned to an independent
republic with a Hutu government. This new administration argued
that as the majority group, Hutu deserved exclusive access
to political power. They excluded the Tutsi minority 
by appointing offices based on population and prohibited the return of Tutsi
families that had fled years earlier. Hutu extremists also circulated propaganda blaming Tutsi for the country’s economic,
social, and political problems. Discontent with their life in exile, a small group of Tutsi insurgents
invaded Rwanda in 1990, beginning a violent civil war. The conflict lasted three years before it
was resolved with a formal peace accord. But the war’s aftermath was
rife with insecurity. While some civilians in both groups
remained amicable, the treaty intensified
political polarization. And in 1994, when a plane carrying
the Hutu Rwandan president was shot down, the conflict broke out anew. This time, Hutu officials had prepared
a deadly response to ensure they stayed in power. Working off a list of targets, government-funded Hutu militias
flooded the streets, perpetrating acts of physical
and sexual violence against Tutsi political enemies
and civilians. Over the chaotic following months, over 1 million Hutu civilians joined
their ranks due to coercion, self-preservation, or the pursuit
of personal agendas. Tutsi victims sought refuge
at churches and schools where they hoped international
organizations would protect them, but no outside party came to their aid. UN soldiers who’d overseen
the Peace Accord were instructed to abandon
Tutsi civilians, and UN leadership refused to acknowledge
the genocide taking place. The violence didn’t end until mid-July, when the Tutsi army—
who instigated the previous civil war— seized control of the country. By the time the fighting was over, roughly 800,000 Rwandans had been killed, and only a small fraction of the
Tutsi population was left alive. In the months that followed, there was no easy strategy for bringing
the killers to justice. The UN established a special tribunal
in Tanzania to try the key perpetrators. But Hutu civilians from every level
of society had committed atrocities against their neighbors, friends,
and even family members. There were roughly 120,000 Rwandans
awaiting trial, and inmates were dying from overcrowding
and poor hygiene. The new Rwandan government estimated 
it would take 100 years to prosecute every accused civilian in national court. So officials determined 
the best path forward involved looking to the country’s past. Rwanda has a traditional process for resolving interpersonal conflicts
called gacaca. Roughly translating
to “justice on the grass,” gacaca had long been used to address
offenses within villages. Local witnesses would offer testimony and could then speak for
or against the accused. Then, appointed lay judges would determine
an appropriate penalty within the community’s means. In the hope of trying perpetrators
more quickly, the government adapted gacaca
for their formal courts. These hybrid trials had 
no professional attorneys or judges, and no evidence outside the spoken word and a case file detailing the crimes
of the accused. All charges were then divided
into four categories: masterminding the genocide
and committing acts of sexual violence, participating in the killings,
physical assault, or destroying Tutsi property. Those found guilty
of the first two categories were entered into the
traditional court system, but the other crimes were
assigned set penalties which could be reduced
if the accused pled guilty. Beginning in 2002, thousands of gacaca
courts convened every week. The process proved faster 
than conventional courts, but Rwandan opinion on the trials
was mixed. Some didn’t want to accuse
their neighbors in a community setting, and many potential witnesses were
intimidated to prevent their testimony. Additionally, while the trial showed that
not all Hutu participated in the killings, the courts only reviewed cases
with Tutsi victims, ignoring the Hutu casualties incurred
during the genocide and the preceding civil war. When the trials concluded in 2012, the courts had convicted
1.7 million individuals. For some families, these verdicts 
helped restore the dignity of those lost in the violence. For others, the trials
were a decade-long reminder of a past they were desperate
to leave behind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Rwanda was colonized by
Options: A. Belgium, B. Germany, C. Germany and Belgium, D. Great Britain
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Which two colonial powers played a significant role in shaping Rwanda's history, particularly in the context of ethnic divisions? Options: A. Germany and France, B. Germany and Belgium, C. Britain and France, D. Britain and Belgium Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary reason for the Hutu revolt in 1959, which led to many Tutsi leaders fleeing the country? Options: A. Economic inequality, B. Lingering anger from colonial propaganda, C. A dispute over land ownership, D. A struggle for independence Correct Option: B
Question 3: What approach would be most effective in addressing ethnic tensions in a country with a history of conflict? Options: A. Enforcing strict segregation between ethnic groups, B. Promoting education and understanding about the country's history and the impact of colonialism, C. Establishing a new government with representation from only the majority ethnic group, D. Focusing solely on economic development Correct Option: B
Question 4: What traditional Rwandan process was adapted for use in formal courts after the genocide to address the large number of cases? Options: A. Gacaca, B. Umuganda, C. Ubudehe, D. Imihigo Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the most significant failure of the United Nations during the Rwandan genocide? Options: A. Failing to provide economic aid to Rwanda, B. Not deploying enough peacekeeping troops, C. Instructing soldiers to abandon Tutsi civilians and refusing to acknowledge the genocide, D. Not imposing sanctions on the Hutu government Correct Option: C
Question 6: Approximately how many Rwandans were awaiting trial for their involvement in the genocide? Options: A. 10,000, B. 50,000, C. 120,000, D. 200,000 Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the Rwandan government categorize crimes committed during the genocide for the purposes of the gacaca trials? Options: A. By the severity of the crime, B. By the location where the crime was committed, C. By the perpetrator's level of involvement, D. Into four categories, including masterminding the genocide, committing acts of sexual violence, participating in the killings, and destroying property Correct Option: D
Question 8: What were some limitations of the gacaca trials in achieving justice for the victims of the genocide? Options: A. The trials were too slow, and the punishments were too lenient, B. The trials were too focused on punishing Hutu perpetrators and ignored the suffering of Hutu victims, C. The trials relied too heavily on spoken testimony and lacked concrete evidence, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What was the outcome of the gacaca trials, which concluded in 2012? Options: A. Over 1 million individuals were acquitted, B. Approximately 1.7 million individuals were convicted, C. The trials resulted in the imprisonment of all Hutu leaders, D. The trials led to the establishment of a new government Correct Option: B
Question 10: How did the gacaca trials affect Rwandan society's ability to heal and move forward from the genocide? Options: A. The trials brought closure to all families affected by the genocide, B. The trials created further divisions within Rwandan society, C. The trials helped to restore dignity to some families but were a painful reminder of the past for others, D. The trials had no significant impact on Rwandan society Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of content (colonial powers in Rwanda) and options (both mention Germany and Belgium as correct answers). The question intent is also similar, as both questions aim to identify the colonial powers that played a significant role in Rwanda's history. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
For 100 days in 1994,
the African country of Rwanda suffered a horrific campaign
of mass murder. Neighbor turned against neighbor
as violence engulfed the region, resulting in the deaths of over one-tenth
of the country’s population. The seeds of this conflict were
planted a century earlier, first when German, and later Belgian,
colonizers arrived in the country. At the time, Rwanda was ruled
by a monarchy of Tutsi, one of the three ethnic groups
comprising the population. Tutsi and the even smaller Twa communities
were minority groups, while Hutu composed the majority. Many Hutus and Tutsi civilians
were on good terms, but colonial powers encouraged
political division. Belgians enforced record keeping
around ethnic identity, and created a public narrative that cast
Tutsi as elite rulers and Hutu as ordinary farmers. Over time, this propaganda led 
to intense political hostility. And while colonial powers had
largely withdrawn by 1959, lingering anger motivated a Hutu revolt, forcing many Tutsi leaders
to flee the country. Over the following decade, Rwanda transitioned to an independent
republic with a Hutu government. This new administration argued
that as the majority group, Hutu deserved exclusive access
to political power. They excluded the Tutsi minority 
by appointing offices based on population and prohibited the return of Tutsi
families that had fled years earlier. Hutu extremists also circulated propaganda blaming Tutsi for the country’s economic,
social, and political problems. Discontent with their life in exile, a small group of Tutsi insurgents
invaded Rwanda in 1990, beginning a violent civil war. The conflict lasted three years before it
was resolved with a formal peace accord. But the war’s aftermath was
rife with insecurity. While some civilians in both groups
remained amicable, the treaty intensified
political polarization. And in 1994, when a plane carrying
the Hutu Rwandan president was shot down, the conflict broke out anew. This time, Hutu officials had prepared
a deadly response to ensure they stayed in power. Working off a list of targets, government-funded Hutu militias
flooded the streets, perpetrating acts of physical
and sexual violence against Tutsi political enemies
and civilians. Over the chaotic following months, over 1 million Hutu civilians joined
their ranks due to coercion, self-preservation, or the pursuit
of personal agendas. Tutsi victims sought refuge
at churches and schools where they hoped international
organizations would protect them, but no outside party came to their aid. UN soldiers who’d overseen
the Peace Accord were instructed to abandon
Tutsi civilians, and UN leadership refused to acknowledge
the genocide taking place. The violence didn’t end until mid-July, when the Tutsi army—
who instigated the previous civil war— seized control of the country. By the time the fighting was over, roughly 800,000 Rwandans had been killed, and only a small fraction of the
Tutsi population was left alive. In the months that followed, there was no easy strategy for bringing
the killers to justice. The UN established a special tribunal
in Tanzania to try the key perpetrators. But Hutu civilians from every level
of society had committed atrocities against their neighbors, friends,
and even family members. There were roughly 120,000 Rwandans
awaiting trial, and inmates were dying from overcrowding
and poor hygiene. The new Rwandan government estimated 
it would take 100 years to prosecute every accused civilian in national court. So officials determined 
the best path forward involved looking to the country’s past. Rwanda has a traditional process for resolving interpersonal conflicts

to “justice on the grass,” gacaca had long been used to address

or against the accused. Then, appointed lay judges would determine
an appropriate penalty within the community’s means. In the hope of trying perpetrators

for their formal courts. These hybrid trials had 
no professional attorneys or judges, and no evidence outside the spoken word and a case file detailing the crimes
of the accused. All charges were then divided
into four categories: masterminding the genocide
and committing acts of sexual violence, participating in the killings,
physical assault, or destroying Tutsi property. Those found guilty
of the first two categories were entered into the
traditional court system, but the other crimes were
assigned set penalties which could be reduced
if the accused pled guilty. Beginning in 2002, thousands of gacaca
courts convened every week. The process proved faster 
than conventional courts, but Rwandan opinion on the trials
was mixed. Some didn’t want to accuse
their neighbors in a community setting, and many potential witnesses were
intimidated to prevent their testimony. Additionally, while the trial showed that
not all Hutu participated in the killings, the courts only reviewed cases
with Tutsi victims, ignoring the Hutu casualties incurred
during the genocide and the preceding civil war. When the trials concluded in 2012, the courts had convicted
1.7 million individuals. For some families, these verdicts 
helped restore the dignity of those lost in the violence. For others, the trials
were a decade-long reminder of a past they were desperate
to leave behind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What ethnic groups is the Rwandan society is composed of?
Options: A. Hutu and Tutsi, B. Hutu, Tutsi and Twa, C.  Hutu and Twa
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
For 100 days in 1994,
the African country of Rwanda suffered a horrific campaign
of mass murder. Neighbor turned against neighbor
as violence engulfed the region, resulting in the deaths of over one-tenth
of the country’s population. The seeds of this conflict were
planted a century earlier, first when German, and later Belgian,
colonizers arrived in the country. At the time, Rwanda was ruled
by a monarchy of Tutsi, one of the three ethnic groups
comprising the population. Tutsi and the even smaller Twa communities
were minority groups, while Hutu composed the majority. Many Hutus and Tutsi civilians
were on good terms, but colonial powers encouraged
political division. Belgians enforced record keeping
around ethnic identity, and created a public narrative that cast
Tutsi as elite rulers and Hutu as ordinary farmers. Over time, this propaganda led 
to intense political hostility. And while colonial powers had
largely withdrawn by 1959, lingering anger motivated a Hutu revolt, forcing many Tutsi leaders
to flee the country. Over the following decade, Rwanda transitioned to an independent
republic with a Hutu government. This new administration argued
that as the majority group, Hutu deserved exclusive access
to political power. They excluded the Tutsi minority 
by appointing offices based on population and prohibited the return of Tutsi
families that had fled years earlier. Hutu extremists also circulated propaganda blaming Tutsi for the country’s economic,
social, and political problems. Discontent with their life in exile, a small group of Tutsi insurgents
invaded Rwanda in 1990, beginning a violent civil war. The conflict lasted three years before it
was resolved with a formal peace accord. But the war’s aftermath was
rife with insecurity. While some civilians in both groups
remained amicable, the treaty intensified
political polarization. And in 1994, when a plane carrying
the Hutu Rwandan president was shot down, the conflict broke out anew. This time, Hutu officials had prepared
a deadly response to ensure they stayed in power. Working off a list of targets, government-funded Hutu militias
flooded the streets, perpetrating acts of physical
and sexual violence against Tutsi political enemies
and civilians. Over the chaotic following months, over 1 million Hutu civilians joined
their ranks due to coercion, self-preservation, or the pursuit
of personal agendas. Tutsi victims sought refuge
at churches and schools where they hoped international
organizations would protect them, but no outside party came to their aid. UN soldiers who’d overseen
the Peace Accord were instructed to abandon
Tutsi civilians, and UN leadership refused to acknowledge
the genocide taking place. The violence didn’t end until mid-July, when the Tutsi army—
who instigated the previous civil war— seized control of the country. By the time the fighting was over, roughly 800,000 Rwandans had been killed, and only a small fraction of the
Tutsi population was left alive. In the months that followed, there was no easy strategy for bringing
the killers to justice. The UN established a special tribunal
in Tanzania to try the key perpetrators. But Hutu civilians from every level
of society had committed atrocities against their neighbors, friends,
and even family members. There were roughly 120,000 Rwandans
awaiting trial, and inmates were dying from overcrowding
and poor hygiene. The new Rwandan government estimated 
it would take 100 years to prosecute every accused civilian in national court. So officials determined 
the best path forward involved looking to the country’s past. Rwanda has a traditional process for resolving interpersonal conflicts
called gacaca. Roughly translating
to “justice on the grass,” gacaca had long been used to address
offenses within villages. Local witnesses would offer testimony and could then speak for
or against the accused. Then, appointed lay judges would determine
an appropriate penalty within the community’s means. In the hope of trying perpetrators
more quickly, the government adapted gacaca
for their formal courts. These hybrid trials had 
no professional attorneys or judges, and no evidence outside the spoken word and a case file detailing the crimes
of the accused. All charges were then divided
into four categories: masterminding the genocide
and committing acts of sexual violence, participating in the killings,
physical assault, or destroying Tutsi property. Those found guilty
of the first two categories were entered into the
traditional court system, but the other crimes were
assigned set penalties which could be reduced
if the accused pled guilty. Beginning in 2002, thousands of gacaca
courts convened every week. The process proved faster 
than conventional courts, but Rwandan opinion on the trials
was mixed. Some didn’t want to accuse
their neighbors in a community setting, and many potential witnesses were
intimidated to prevent their testimony. Additionally, while the trial showed that
not all Hutu participated in the killings, the courts only reviewed cases
with Tutsi victims, ignoring the Hutu casualties incurred
during the genocide and the preceding civil war. When the trials concluded in 2012, the courts had convicted
1.7 million individuals. For some families, these verdicts 
helped restore the dignity of those lost in the violence. For others, the trials
were a decade-long reminder of a past they were desperate
to leave behind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: At the time of the genocide in 1994, Rwanda’s government was _______.
Options: A. Hutu, B. Tutsi, C. Twa
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Which two colonial powers played a significant role in shaping Rwanda's history, particularly in the context of ethnic divisions? Options: A. Germany and France, B. Germany and Belgium, C. Britain and France, D. Britain and Belgium Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary reason for the Hutu revolt in 1959, which led to many Tutsi leaders fleeing the country? Options: A. Economic inequality, B. Lingering anger from colonial propaganda, C. A dispute over land ownership, D. A struggle for independence Correct Option: B
Question 3: What approach would be most effective in addressing ethnic tensions in a country with a history of conflict? Options: A. Enforcing strict segregation between ethnic groups, B. Promoting education and understanding about the country's history and the impact of colonialism, C. Establishing a new government with representation from only the majority ethnic group, D. Focusing solely on economic development Correct Option: B
Question 4: What traditional Rwandan process was adapted for use in formal courts after the genocide to address the large number of cases? Options: A. Gacaca, B. Umuganda, C. Ubudehe, D. Imihigo Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the most significant failure of the United Nations during the Rwandan genocide? Options: A. Failing to provide economic aid to Rwanda, B. Not deploying enough peacekeeping troops, C. Instructing soldiers to abandon Tutsi civilians and refusing to acknowledge the genocide, D. Not imposing sanctions on the Hutu government Correct Option: C
Question 6: Approximately how many Rwandans were awaiting trial for their involvement in the genocide? Options: A. 10,000, B. 50,000, C. 120,000, D. 200,000 Correct Option: C
Question 7: How did the Rwandan government categorize crimes committed during the genocide for the purposes of the gacaca trials? Options: A. By the severity of the crime, B. By the location where the crime was committed, C. By the perpetrator's level of involvement, D. Into four categories, including masterminding the genocide, committing acts of sexual violence, participating in the killings, and destroying property Correct Option: D
Question 8: What were some limitations of the gacaca trials in achieving justice for the victims of the genocide? Options: A. The trials were too slow, and the punishments were too lenient, B. The trials were too focused on punishing Hutu perpetrators and ignored the suffering of Hutu victims, C. The trials relied too heavily on spoken testimony and lacked concrete evidence, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What was the outcome of the gacaca trials, which concluded in 2012? Options: A. Over 1 million individuals were acquitted, B. Approximately 1.7 million individuals were convicted, C. The trials resulted in the imprisonment of all Hutu leaders, D. The trials led to the establishment of a new government Correct Option: B
Question 10: How did the gacaca trials affect Rwandan society's ability to heal and move forward from the genocide? Options: A. The trials brought closure to all families affected by the genocide, B. The trials created further divisions within Rwandan society, C. The trials helped to restore dignity to some families but were a painful reminder of the past for others, D. The trials had no significant impact on Rwandan society Correct Option: C

Question: Which ethnic group held the majority of government positions in Rwanda in 1994?
Options: A. Hutu, B. Tutsi, C. Twa

However, this question is not present among the generated MCQs. Among the provided options, Question 2 is the closest, but it does not directly address the composition of the Rwandan government in 1994.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
For 100 days in 1994,
the African country of Rwanda suffered a horrific campaign
of mass murder. Neighbor turned against neighbor
as violence engulfed the region, resulting in the deaths of over one-tenth
of the country’s population. The seeds of this conflict were
planted a century earlier, first when German, and later Belgian,
colonizers arrived in the country. At the time, Rwanda was ruled
by a monarchy of Tutsi, one of the three ethnic groups
comprising the population. Tutsi and the even smaller Twa communities
were minority groups, while Hutu composed the majority. Many Hutus and Tutsi civilians
were on good terms, but colonial powers encouraged
political division. Belgians enforced record keeping
around ethnic identity, and created a public narrative that cast
Tutsi as elite rulers and Hutu as ordinary farmers. Over time, this propaganda led 
to intense political hostility. And while colonial powers had
largely withdrawn by 1959, lingering anger motivated a Hutu revolt, forcing many Tutsi leaders
to flee the country. Over the following decade, Rwanda transitioned to an independent
republic with a Hutu government. This new administration argued
that as the majority group, Hutu deserved exclusive access
to political power. They excluded the Tutsi minority 
by appointing offices based on population and prohibited the return of Tutsi
families that had fled years earlier. Hutu extremists also circulated propaganda blaming Tutsi for the country’s economic,
social, and political problems. Discontent with their life in exile, a small group of Tutsi insurgents
invaded Rwanda in 1990, beginning a violent civil war. The conflict lasted three years before it
was resolved with a formal peace accord. But the war’s aftermath was
rife with insecurity. While some civilians in both groups
remained amicable, the treaty intensified
political polarization. And in 1994, when a plane carrying
the Hutu Rwandan president was shot down, the conflict broke out anew. This time, Hutu officials had prepared
a deadly response to ensure they stayed in power. Working off a list of targets, government-funded Hutu militias
flooded the streets, perpetrating acts of physical
and sexual violence against Tutsi political enemies
and civilians. Over the chaotic following months, over 1 million Hutu civilians joined
their ranks due to coercion, self-preservation, or the pursuit
of personal agendas. Tutsi victims sought refuge
at churches and schools where they hoped international
organizations would protect them, but no outside party came to their aid. UN soldiers who’d overseen
the Peace Accord were instructed to abandon
Tutsi civilians, and UN leadership refused to acknowledge
the genocide taking place. The violence didn’t end until mid-July, when the Tutsi army—
who instigated the previous civil war— seized control of the country. By the time the fighting was over, roughly 800,000 Rwandans had been killed, and only a small fraction of the
Tutsi population was left alive. In the months that followed, there was no easy strategy for bringing
the killers to justice. The UN established a special tribunal
in Tanzania to try the key perpetrators. But Hutu civilians from every level
of society had committed atrocities against their neighbors, friends,
and even family members. There were roughly 120,000 Rwandans
awaiting trial, and inmates were dying from overcrowding
and poor hygiene. The new Rwandan government estimated 
it would take 100 years to prosecute every accused civilian in national court. So officials determined 
the best path forward involved looking to the country’s past. Rwanda has a traditional process for resolving interpersonal conflicts
called gacaca. Roughly translating
to “justice on the grass,” gacaca had long been used to address
offenses within villages. Local witnesses would offer testimony and could then speak for
or against the accused. Then, appointed lay judges would determine
an appropriate penalty within the community’s means. In the hope of trying perpetrators
more quickly, the government adapted gacaca
for their formal courts. These hybrid trials had 
no professional attorneys or judges, and no evidence outside the spoken word and a case file detailing the crimes
of the accused. All charges were then divided
into four categories: masterminding the genocide
and committing acts of sexual violence, participating in the killings,
physical assault, or destroying Tutsi property. Those found guilty
of the first two categories were entered into the
traditional court system, but the other crimes were
assigned set penalties which could be reduced
if the accused pled guilty. Beginning in 2002, thousands of gacaca
courts convened every week. The process proved faster 
than conventional courts, but Rwandan opinion on the trials
was mixed. Some didn’t want to accuse
their neighbors in a community setting, and many potential witnesses were
intimidated to prevent their testimony. Additionally, while the trial showed that
not all Hutu participated in the killings, the courts only reviewed cases
with Tutsi victims, ignoring the Hutu casualties incurred
during the genocide and the preceding civil war. When the trials concluded in 2012, the courts had convicted
1.7 million individuals. For some families, these verdicts 
helped restore the dignity of those lost in the violence. For others, the trials
were a decade-long reminder of a past they were desperate
to leave behind.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In order to come to terms with the past, village tribunal called gacaca, which translates ___________, were set up .
Options: A. Justice in the grass, B. Fair trials for all, C. The truth shall heal, D. End to Impunity
Correct Option: A

Question 3: What approach would be most effective in addressing ethnic tensions in a country with a history of conflict? Options: A. Enforcing strict segregation between ethnic groups, B. Promoting education and understanding about the country's history and the impact of colonialism, C. Establishing a new government with representation from only the majority ethnic group, D. Focusing solely on economic development Correct Option: B
Question 4: What traditional Rwandan process was adapted for use in formal courts after the genocide to address the large number of cases? Options: A. Gacaca, B. Umuganda, C. Ubudehe, D. Imihigo Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the most significant failure of the United Nations during the Rwandan genocide? Options: A. Failing to provide economic aid to Rwanda, B. Not deploying enough peacekeeping troops, C. Instructing soldiers to abandon Tutsi civilians and refusing to acknowledge the genocide, D. Not imposing sanctions on the Hutu government Correct Option: C

By the location where the crime was committed, C. By the perpetrator's level of involvement, D. The trials were too focused on punishing Hutu perpetrators and ignored the suffering of Hutu victims, C. The trials relied too heavily on spoken testimony and lacked concrete evidence, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: What was the outcome of the gacaca trials, which concluded in 2012? Options: A. Over 1 million individuals were acquitted, B. Approximately 1.7 million individuals were convicted, C. The trials resulted in the imprisonment of all Hutu leaders, D. The trials led to the establishment of a new government Correct Option: B
Question 10: How did the gacaca trials affect Rwandan society's ability to heal and move forward from the genocide? Options: A. The trials brought closure to all families affected by the genocide, B. The trials created further divisions within Rwandan society, C. The trials helped to restore dignity to some families but were a painful reminder of the past for others, D. The trials had no significant impact on Rwandan society Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

**Question 4: What traditional Rwandan process was adapted for use in formal courts after the genocide to address the large number of cases? Options: A. Gacaca, B. Umuganda, C. Ubudehe, D. Imihigo Correct Option: A**

1. Refers to the traditional Rwandan process of gacaca.
2. Mentions its adaptation for use in formal courts after the genocide.
3. Has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, which is to understand the role of gacaca in addressing the past.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 5

**Transcript**:
For 100 days in 1994,
the African country of Rwanda suffered a horrific campaign
of mass murder. Neighbor turned against neighbor
as violence engulfed the region, resulting in the deaths of over one-tenth
of the country’s population. The seeds of this conflict were
planted a century earlier, first when German, and later Belgian,
colonizers arrived in the country. At the time, Rwanda was ruled
by a monarchy of Tutsi, one of the three ethnic groups
comprising the population. Tutsi and the even smaller Twa communities
were minority groups, while Hutu composed the majority. Many Hutus and Tutsi civilians
were on good terms, but colonial powers encouraged
political division. Belgians enforced record keeping
around ethnic identity, and created a public narrative that cast
Tutsi as elite rulers and Hutu as ordinary farmers. Over time, this propaganda led 
to intense political hostility. And while colonial powers had
largely withdrawn by 1959, lingering anger motivated a Hutu revolt, forcing many Tutsi leaders
to flee the country. Over the following decade, Rwanda transitioned to an independent
republic with a Hutu government. This new administration argued
that as the majority group, Hutu deserved exclusive access
to political power. They excluded the Tutsi minority 
by appointing offices based on population and prohibited the return of Tutsi
families that had fled years earlier. Hutu extremists also circulated propaganda blaming Tutsi for the country’s economic,
social, and political problems. Discontent with their life in exile, a small group of Tutsi insurgents
invaded Rwanda in 1990, beginning a violent civil war. The conflict lasted three years before it
was resolved with a formal peace accord. But the war’s aftermath was
rife with insecurity. While some civilians in both groups
remained amicable, the treaty intensified
political polarization. And in 1994, when a plane carrying
the Hutu Rwandan president was shot down, the conflict broke out anew. This time, Hutu officials had prepared
a deadly response to ensure they stayed in power. Working off a list of targets, government-funded Hutu militias
flooded the streets, perpetrating acts of physical
and sexual violence against Tutsi political enemies
and civilians. Over the chaotic following months, over 1 million Hutu civilians joined
their ranks due to coercion, self-preservation, or the pursuit
of personal agendas. Tutsi victims sought refuge
at churches and schools where they hoped international
organizations would protect them, but no outside party came to their aid. UN soldiers who’d overseen
the Peace Accord were instructed to abandon
Tutsi civilians, and UN leadership refused to acknowledge
the genocide taking place. The violence didn’t end until mid-July, when the Tutsi army—
who instigated the previous civil war— seized control of the country. By the time the fighting was over, roughly 800,000 Rwandans had been killed, and only a small fraction of the
Tutsi population was left alive. In the months that followed, there was no easy strategy for bringing
the killers to justice. The UN established a special tribunal
in Tanzania to try the key perpetrators. But Hutu civilians from every level
of society had committed atrocities against their neighbors, friends,
and even family members. There were roughly 120,000 Rwandans
awaiting trial, and inmates were dying from overcrowding
and poor hygiene. The new Rwandan government estimated 
it would take 100 years to prosecute every accused civilian in national court. So officials determined 
the best path forward involved looking to the country’s past. Rwanda has a traditional process for resolving interpersonal conflicts
called gacaca. Roughly translating
to “justice on the grass,” gacaca had long been used to address
offenses within villages. Local witnesses would offer testimony and could then speak for
or against the accused. Then, appointed lay judges would determine
an appropriate penalty within the community’s means. In the hope of trying perpetrators
more quickly, the government adapted gacaca
for their formal courts. These hybrid trials had 
no professional attorneys or judges, and no evidence outside the spoken word and a case file detailing the crimes
of the accused. All charges were then divided
into four categories: masterminding the genocide
and committing acts of sexual violence, participating in the killings,
physical assault, or destroying Tutsi property. Those found guilty
of the first two categories were entered into the
traditional court system, but the other crimes were
assigned set penalties which could be reduced
if the accused pled guilty. Beginning in 2002, thousands of gacaca
courts convened every week. The process proved faster 
than conventional courts, but Rwandan opinion on the trials
was mixed. Some didn’t want to accuse
their neighbors in a community setting, and many potential witnesses were
intimidated to prevent their testimony. Additionally, while the trial showed that
not all Hutu participated in the killings, the courts only reviewed cases
with Tutsi victims, ignoring the Hutu casualties incurred
during the genocide and the preceding civil war. When the trials concluded in 2012, the courts had convicted
1.7 million individuals. For some families, these verdicts 
helped restore the dignity of those lost in the violence. For others, the trials
were a decade-long reminder of a past they were desperate
to leave behind.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the spring of 1954, the press excitedly gathered around
Bell Laboratories’ latest invention— a silicon-based solar cell
that could efficiently convert the sun's energy into electrical current. The creation was celebrated
as the dawn of a new era, as reporters touted that civilization
would soon run on the sun’s limitless energy. But the dream had a catch,
as this first commercially sold solar cell cost around $300 per watt, meaning at its current rate, it would cost well over a million
to buy a unit large enough to power a single home. But today in many countries solar is the cheapest form
of energy to produce, surpassing fossil fuel alternatives
like coal and natural gas. Millions of homes are equipped
with rooftop solar, with most units paying for themselves
in their first 7 to 12 years and then generating further savings. So how did solar become so affordable? A turning point in solar’s
price history occurred on the floor of Germany’s parliament,
where in 2000, Herman Scheer introduced 
the Renewable Energy Sources Act. This legislation laid out a vision
for the country’s energy future in solar and wind. It incentivized citizens to personally
invest in rooftop solar panels by guaranteeing payment to homeowners
for the renewable energy they generated and sold to the grid. The pay rate for this electricity was
highly subsidized, at times reaching four times
the market price. Several other countries soon
followed Germany’s example, implementing similar
policies and incentives to drive their country’s solar use. This created unprecedented demand
for solar panels worldwide. Manufacturers were
able to scale up production and innovate in ways that cut costs. As a result, solar panel prices dropped,
while efficiency grew. Today, a 46-square-meter rooftop
solar unit is often efficient enough to fully power a home, and this residential unit
no longer costs millions— in the US in 2022,  the average
consumer cost of a rooftop solar unit ranged from around $17,000 to $23,000. These prices dropped by over 60%
between 2010 and 2020 alone. So how much money can you save
by switching to solar? US solar equipped homeowners
can save around $1,500 per year on their energy bills, equating to a net savings of $10,000
to $30,000 during the unit’s lifetime. Month-to-month savings
tend to vary, based on the amount of direct sunlight 
your panel receives, weather conditions, and the price
of electricity where you live. But not everyone can get solar. Adopting solar can be difficult
for renters, and in many countries, more than 25% of adults don’t own
their own homes. Even if you do, your roof must meet
certain orientation and tilt requirements to make solar a worthwhile investment. And while units often pay for themselves
through offset energy costs, the initial purchase and installation
price for solar can be expensive. But several companies have adopted
solar leasing models, where they finance the material costs, installation, and upkeep
of the rooftop systems. Homeowners can then buy the panel’s
generated electricity at a fixed rate that’s generally lower
than the local utility’s price. Still, many are working
towards community-based solutions, which would enable entire neighborhoods
to profit from solar use. Europe is home to more than 7,000
community energy associations, where local members collectively
invest in wind turbines and solar panels to power their local grid. In 2005, the German town of Wolfhagen
created an 800 member citizens co-op, which communally invested $2.84 million to buy up 25% of the local energy company and expand its renewables program. Today, its turbines and panels
generate enough energy to meet the town’s needs and then some. Surplus energy is sold
to neighboring towns, and profits are reinvested
back into the community. For many, the appeal of solar
goes beyond just savings. Homes equipped with it are
more climate resilient, because they can be protected
from utility grid outages and brownouts. Not to mention solar’s key role
in decarbonizing the energy grid. By working together with larger-scale
wind and solar farms, rooftop solar units help reduce
our reliance on fossil fuels, paving the way for a cleaner
and more reliable energy future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When solar cells were first invented in the 1950s, what was the cost the electricity they produced?
Options: A. $100/Watt, B. $200/Watt, C. $300/Watt, D. $400/Watt
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what year did Bell Laboratories introduce a silicon-based solar cell that could efficiently convert the sun's energy into electrical current? Options: A. 1950, B. 1954, C. 1960, D. 1964 Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary reason why the initial solar cell invention was not widely adopted for household use in the 1950s? Options: A. It was not efficient enough, B. It was too heavy, C. It was too expensive, costing around $300 per watt, D. It was not durable Correct Option: C
Question 3: What policy, introduced by Herman Scheer in 2000, played a significant role in driving down the cost of solar panels in Germany? Options: A. Renewable Energy Sources Act, B. Solar Panel Subsidy Act, C. Clean Energy Initiative, D. Green Energy Policy Correct Option: A
Question 4: How did the Renewable Energy Sources Act incentivize citizens to invest in rooftop solar panels in Germany? Options: A. By providing tax credits for solar panel purchases, B. By guaranteeing payment for the renewable energy generated and sold to the grid at a subsidized rate, C. By offering discounts on solar panel purchases, D. By providing free installation for low-income households Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the result of the increased demand for solar panels worldwide, driven by policies like the Renewable Energy Sources Act? Options: A. Manufacturers reduced production to meet decreasing demand, B. Manufacturers increased production and innovated to cut costs, leading to lower prices, C. The price of solar panels increased due to higher demand, D. The efficiency of solar panels decreased as manufacturers prioritized cost over quality Correct Option: B
Question 6: Approximately how much can US homeowners save per year on their energy bills by switching to solar, according to the transcript? Options: A. $500, B. $1,000, C. $1,500, D. $2,000 Correct Option: C
Question 7: What are some potential barriers to adopting solar energy for some individuals, according to the transcript? Options: A. High upfront costs, B. Limited sunlight in their area, C. Not owning their own home, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is an alternative to purchasing solar panels outright, mentioned in the transcript as a solution for homeowners who cannot afford the upfront costs? Options: A. Solar leasing models, where companies finance the material costs and installation, B. Community-based solutions, where neighborhoods collectively invest in solar panels, C. Government subsidies for low-income households, D. Crowdfunding campaigns to raise money for solar panel purchases Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is an example of a community-based solution to solar energy adoption, mentioned in the transcript as a successful model in Europe? Options: A. A neighborhood collectively investing in a single solar panel system, B. A town creating a citizens co-op to invest in wind turbines and solar panels, like the German town of Wolfhagen, C. A city offering tax credits for solar panel purchases, D. A state implementing a renewable energy mandate for utilities Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is a benefit of solar energy beyond just cost savings, mentioned in the transcript as an advantage for homes equipped with solar panels? Options: A. Increased reliance on fossil fuels, B. Improved climate resilience and protection from grid outages, C. Reduced energy efficiency and increased energy consumption, D. Increased greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (the cost of solar cells when they were first invented) and content (the cost being around $300 per watt). Although the wording of the question is different, the meaning and the correct answer are the same.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the spring of 1954, the press excitedly gathered around
Bell Laboratories’ latest invention— a silicon-based solar cell
that could efficiently convert the sun's energy into electrical current. The creation was celebrated
as the dawn of a new era, as reporters touted that civilization
would soon run on the sun’s limitless energy. But the dream had a catch,
as this first commercially sold solar cell cost around $300 per watt, meaning at its current rate, it would cost well over a million
to buy a unit large enough to power a single home. But today in many countries solar is the cheapest form
of energy to produce, surpassing fossil fuel alternatives
like coal and natural gas. Millions of homes are equipped
with rooftop solar, with most units paying for themselves
in their first 7 to 12 years and then generating further savings. So how did solar become so affordable? A turning point in solar’s
price history occurred on the floor of Germany’s parliament,
where in 2000, Herman Scheer introduced 
the Renewable Energy Sources Act. This legislation laid out a vision
for the country’s energy future in solar and wind. It incentivized citizens to personally
invest in rooftop solar panels by guaranteeing payment to homeowners
for the renewable energy they generated and sold to the grid. The pay rate for this electricity was
highly subsidized, at times reaching four times
the market price. Several other countries soon
followed Germany’s example, implementing similar
policies and incentives to drive their country’s solar use. This created unprecedented demand
for solar panels worldwide. Manufacturers were
able to scale up production and innovate in ways that cut costs. As a result, solar panel prices dropped,
while efficiency grew. Today, a 46-square-meter rooftop
solar unit is often efficient enough to fully power a home, and this residential unit
no longer costs millions— in the US in 2022,  the average
consumer cost of a rooftop solar unit ranged from around $17,000 to $23,000. These prices dropped by over 60%
between 2010 and 2020 alone. So how much money can you save
by switching to solar? US solar equipped homeowners
can save around $1,500 per year on their energy bills, equating to a net savings of $10,000
to $30,000 during the unit’s lifetime. Month-to-month savings
tend to vary, based on the amount of direct sunlight 
your panel receives, weather conditions, and the price
of electricity where you live. But not everyone can get solar. Adopting solar can be difficult
for renters, and in many countries, more than 25% of adults don’t own
their own homes. Even if you do, your roof must meet
certain orientation and tilt requirements to make solar a worthwhile investment. And while units often pay for themselves
through offset energy costs, the initial purchase and installation
price for solar can be expensive. But several companies have adopted
solar leasing models, where they finance the material costs, installation, and upkeep
of the rooftop systems. Homeowners can then buy the panel’s
generated electricity at a fixed rate that’s generally lower
than the local utility’s price. Still, many are working
towards community-based solutions, which would enable entire neighborhoods
to profit from solar use. Europe is home to more than 7,000
community energy associations, where local members collectively
invest in wind turbines and solar panels to power their local grid. In 2005, the German town of Wolfhagen
created an 800 member citizens co-op, which communally invested $2.84 million to buy up 25% of the local energy company and expand its renewables program. Today, its turbines and panels
generate enough energy to meet the town’s needs and then some. Surplus energy is sold
to neighboring towns, and profits are reinvested
back into the community. For many, the appeal of solar
goes beyond just savings. Homes equipped with it are
more climate resilient, because they can be protected
from utility grid outages and brownouts. Not to mention solar’s key role
in decarbonizing the energy grid. By working together with larger-scale
wind and solar farms, rooftop solar units help reduce
our reliance on fossil fuels, paving the way for a cleaner
and more reliable energy future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In many countries, solar energy is the cheapest form of electricity. Cheaper, even, than fossil fuel generated electricity.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: In what year did Bell Laboratories introduce a silicon-based solar cell that could efficiently convert the sun's energy into electrical current? Options: A. 1950, B. 1954, C. 1960, D. 1964 Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the primary reason why the initial solar cell invention was not widely adopted for household use in the 1950s? Options: A. It was not efficient enough, B. It was too heavy, C. It was too expensive, costing around $300 per watt, D. It was not durable Correct Option: C
Question 3: What policy, introduced by Herman Scheer in 2000, played a significant role in driving down the cost of solar panels in Germany? Options: A. Renewable Energy Sources Act, B. Solar Panel Subsidy Act, C. Clean Energy Initiative, D. Green Energy Policy Correct Option: A
Question 4: How did the Renewable Energy Sources Act incentivize citizens to invest in rooftop solar panels in Germany? Options: A. By providing tax credits for solar panel purchases, B. By guaranteeing payment for the renewable energy generated and sold to the grid at a subsidized rate, C. By offering discounts on solar panel purchases, D. By providing free installation for low-income households Correct Option: B
Question 5: What was the result of the increased demand for solar panels worldwide, driven by policies like the Renewable Energy Sources Act? Options: A. Manufacturers reduced production to meet decreasing demand, B. Manufacturers increased production and innovated to cut costs, leading to lower prices, C. The price of solar panels increased due to higher demand, D. The efficiency of solar panels decreased as manufacturers prioritized cost over quality Correct Option: B
Question 6: Approximately how much can US homeowners save per year on their energy bills by switching to solar, according to the transcript? Options: A. $500, B. $1,000, C. $1,500, D. $2,000 Correct Option: C
Question 7: What are some potential barriers to adopting solar energy for some individuals, according to the transcript? Options: A. High upfront costs, B. Limited sunlight in their area, C. Not owning their own home, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is an alternative to purchasing solar panels outright, mentioned in the transcript as a solution for homeowners who cannot afford the upfront costs? Options: A. Solar leasing models, where companies finance the material costs and installation, B. Community-based solutions, where neighborhoods collectively invest in solar panels, C. Government subsidies for low-income households, D. Crowdfunding campaigns to raise money for solar panel purchases Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is an example of a community-based solution to solar energy adoption, mentioned in the transcript as a successful model in Europe? Options: A. A neighborhood collectively investing in a single solar panel system, B. A town creating a citizens co-op to invest in wind turbines and solar panels, like the German town of Wolfhagen, C. A city offering tax credits for solar panel purchases, D. A state implementing a renewable energy mandate for utilities Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is a benefit of solar energy beyond just cost savings, mentioned in the transcript as an advantage for homes equipped with solar panels? Options: A. Increased reliance on fossil fuels, B. Improved climate resilience and protection from grid outages, C. Reduced energy efficiency and increased energy consumption, D. Increased greenhouse gas emissions and air pollution Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is related to the topic and has a similar intent.

The ground truth MCQ states that "In many countries, solar energy is the cheapest form of electricity. Cheaper, even, than fossil fuel generated electricity." This statement is supported by the transcript, which mentions that "today in many countries solar is the cheapest form of energy to produce, surpassing fossil fuel alternatives like coal and natural gas."

Among the generated MCQs, Question 5 is the most relevant to the topic, but it does not directly compare the cost of solar energy to fossil fuels. However, it does mention the result of increased demand for solar panels, which led to lower prices.

A more suitable match is not available among the generated MCQs. However, if I had to choose one, I would suggest Question 5 as the most similar generated MCQ, although it is not a direct match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In the spring of 1954, the press excitedly gathered around
Bell Laboratories’ latest invention— a silicon-based solar cell
that could efficiently convert the sun's energy into electrical current. The creation was celebrated
as the dawn of a new era, as reporters touted that civilization
would soon run on the sun’s limitless energy. But the dream had a catch,
as this first commercially sold solar cell cost around $300 per watt, meaning at its current rate, it would cost well over a million
to buy a unit large enough to power a single home. But today in many countries solar is the cheapest form
of energy to produce, surpassing fossil fuel alternatives
like coal and natural gas. Millions of homes are equipped
with rooftop solar, with most units paying for themselves
in their first 7 to 12 years and then generating further savings. So how did solar become so affordable? A turning point in solar’s
price history occurred on the floor of Germany’s parliament,
where in 2000, Herman Scheer introduced 
the Renewable Energy Sources Act. This legislation laid out a vision
for the country’s energy future in solar and wind. It incentivized citizens to personally
invest in rooftop solar panels by guaranteeing payment to homeowners
for the renewable energy they generated and sold to the grid. The pay rate for this electricity was
highly subsidized, at times reaching four times
the market price. Several other countries soon
followed Germany’s example, implementing similar
policies and incentives to drive their country’s solar use. This created unprecedented demand
for solar panels worldwide. Manufacturers were
able to scale up production and innovate in ways that cut costs. As a result, solar panel prices dropped,
while efficiency grew. Today, a 46-square-meter rooftop
solar unit is often efficient enough to fully power a home, and this residential unit
no longer costs millions— in the US in 2022,  the average
consumer cost of a rooftop solar unit ranged from around $17,000 to $23,000. These prices dropped by over 60%
between 2010 and 2020 alone. So how much money can you save
by switching to solar? US solar equipped homeowners
can save around $1,500 per year on their energy bills, equating to a net savings of $10,000
to $30,000 during the unit’s lifetime. Month-to-month savings
tend to vary, based on the amount of direct sunlight 
your panel receives, weather conditions, and the price
of electricity where you live. But not everyone can get solar. Adopting solar can be difficult
for renters, and in many countries, more than 25% of adults don’t own
their own homes. Even if you do, your roof must meet
certain orientation and tilt requirements to make solar a worthwhile investment. And while units often pay for themselves
through offset energy costs, the initial purchase and installation
price for solar can be expensive. But several companies have adopted
solar leasing models, where they finance the material costs, installation, and upkeep
of the rooftop systems. Homeowners can then buy the panel’s
generated electricity at a fixed rate that’s generally lower
than the local utility’s price. Still, many are working
towards community-based solutions, which would enable entire neighborhoods
to profit from solar use. Europe is home to more than 7,000
community energy associations, where local members collectively
invest in wind turbines and solar panels to power their local grid. In 2005, the German town of Wolfhagen
created an 800 member citizens co-op, which communally invested $2.84 million to buy up 25% of the local energy company and expand its renewables program. Today, its turbines and panels
generate enough energy to meet the town’s needs and then some. Surplus energy is sold
to neighboring towns, and profits are reinvested
back into the community. For many, the appeal of solar
goes beyond just savings. Homes equipped with it are
more climate resilient, because they can be protected
from utility grid outages and brownouts. Not to mention solar’s key role
in decarbonizing the energy grid. By working together with larger-scale
wind and solar farms, rooftop solar units help reduce
our reliance on fossil fuels, paving the way for a cleaner
and more reliable energy future.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Between 2010 and 2020 what was the change in price for solar panels on homes?
Options: A. Increase of 20%, B. Decrease of 20 %, C. Decrease of 40%, D. Decrease of 60%
Correct Option: D

In the spring of 1954, the press excitedly gathered around
Bell Laboratories’ latest invention— a silicon-based solar cell

as the dawn of a new era, as reporters touted that civilization
would soon run on the sun’s limitless energy. But the dream had a catch,

to buy a unit large enough to power a single home. But today in many countries solar is the cheapest form
of energy to produce, surpassing fossil fuel alternatives
like coal and natural gas. Millions of homes are equipped
with rooftop solar, with most units paying for themselves
in their first 7 to 12 years and then generating further savings. So how did solar become so affordable? A turning point in solar’s

where in 2000, Herman Scheer introduced 
the Renewable Energy Sources Act. This legislation laid out a vision
for the country’s energy future in solar and wind. It incentivized citizens to personally

for the renewable energy they generated and sold to the grid. The pay rate for this electricity was

policies and incentives to drive their country’s solar use. This created unprecedented demand

can save around $1,500 per year on their energy bills, equating to a net savings of $10,000
to $30,000 during the unit’s lifetime. Month-to-month savings
tend to vary, based on the amount of direct sunlight 
your panel receives, weather conditions, and the price
of electricity where you live. But not everyone can get solar. Adopting solar can be difficult

price for solar can be expensive. But several companies have adopted

of the rooftop systems. Homeowners can then buy the panel’s
generated electricity at a fixed rate that’s generally lower
than the local utility’s price. Still, many are working
towards community-based solutions, which would enable entire neighborhoods
to profit from solar use. Europe is home to more than 7,000

invest in wind turbines and solar panels to power their local grid. In 2005, the German town of Wolfhagen
created an 800 member citizens co-op, which communally invested $2.84 million to buy up 25% of the local energy company and expand its renewables program. Today, its turbines and panels

to neighboring towns, and profits are reinvested
back into the community. For many, the appeal of solar
goes beyond just savings. Homes equipped with it are
more climate resilient, because they can be protected
from utility grid outages and brownouts. Not to mention solar’s key role
in decarbonizing the energy grid. By working together with larger-scale
wind and solar farms, rooftop solar units help reduce
our reliance on fossil fuels, paving the way for a cleaner
and more reliable energy future.
